conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, I’m Student_E and I’m very interested in joining School_D. I’m drawn to your academic environment and would be excited to contribute positively to the school community. School_D is one of my top choices, and I would be thrilled to accept an offer if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, but School_C ranks me 4th (behind B, C, D) and several of those students also highly prefer School_C, so applying there first has a significant rejection risk. School_D is my 2nd choice and ranks me 4th as well, but importantly Student_D and Student_A (who are ahead of me at School_D) both strongly prefer School_B/School_C and are likely to match elsewhere. Meanwhile, I am the top priority at School_A and School_B, but those are lower on my true list (A is 3rd, B is last). To maximize my outcome while avoiding an early lock-in to a lower option, I will apply to School_D now as a strong-but-not-too-risky move, aiming to secure my 2nd choice before considering my safety options (especially School_A, where I have top priority).

conversation.message: Dear Student_E, thank you for your application and for your interest in School_D. After reviewing priorities for this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your time and wish you the best in the remainder of the process.
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_D’s true priority list (behind Student_D, Student_A, Student_C). We have quota 1 and it’s only round 1; no other applicants have contacted us yet, but higher-priority students may apply later. Student_E’s own preferences rank School_D as 2nd (after School_C), so even if we accept now we lock in a match, but that could prevent us from matching with a higher-priority student. Given the objective to match as high as possible on our priority list and the early stage of the market, it is better to reject Student_E now and keep the seat available for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_D. School_C is one of my top choices because I value a strong academic environment and I believe I would contribute positively to your community. I’m ready to commit if offered a place and would be excited to join School_C this year. Thank you for considering my application.

An early [APPLY] is likely to be rejected if higher-priority applicants apply. School_C is my #2 and I am 3rd in School_C's priority, behind Student_B and Student_C. Student_B ranks School_C #3, Student_C ranks it #2, and Student_E ranks it #1, so there will be competition, but I have a reasonable priority position. I will apply to School_C now to try to secure a high outcome rather than risk ending up much lower later.

conversation.message: Dear Student_D, thank you for your thoughtful application and your interest in School_C. After reviewing applications received this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your time and wish you the very best with your other choices.
conversation.thought: We have quota 1 and received APPLY from Student_D and Student_B in round 1. Our true priority ranks Student_B above Student_D (B > C > D > E > A). Since Student_B is available and has applied, accepting Student_D now would block a higher-priority match. Therefore reject Student_D to preserve the seat for Student_B.

conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_B and I’m very excited about the possibility of joining School_C. Therefore I will apply to School_C immediately and emphasize strong fit and commitment.

Accepting Student_B immediately secures my top-choice student and is consistent with my objective to match as high as possible on my priority list; there is no higher-ranked candidate than Student_B, so waiting provides no upside and risks losing Student_B to School_A/School_B (which Student_B prefers over School_C). History shows I already rejected Student_D, and even if reconsidered, Student_D is ranked below Student_B. Therefore, I should accept Student_B now.

Given quota 1, accepting Student_C now would lock me in and could forgo a potential match with Student_B later. Since the game allows up to 30 rounds and there is no penalty stated for waiting, the strategically better move is to reject Student_C now to preserve the seat for Student_B (more plausible than Student_E).

conversation.message: Dear School_B Admissions, [APPLY] School_B is my first choice and I’m very eager to join your community. I’m committed to contributing actively in classes and school activities and would accept an offer immediately. Thank you for considering my application.
